hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H1: Rackspace transmits shocks to customers rather than absorbing them, due to zero margin buffer
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence of thin margins preventing shock absorption
Evidence of cost pass-through attempts to customers
Evidence of service reductions during financial stress
Historical shock transmission examples
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of shock absorption without customer impact
Cost restructuring preserving margins during shocks
hypothesis_framework.notes: Email 706% price increase attempted transmission, VMware costs partially passed through creating churn, CapEx declining 25% shows underinvestment likely degrading service. Fixed costs prevent absorption. Hypothesis supported.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H2: External shocks accelerate value migration from Rackspace to hyperscalers and platforms
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that recession/stress drives customers to lower-cost hyperscaler-direct
Evidence that shocks increase platform vendor leverage over Rackspace
Evidence that recovery benefits platforms more than intermediaries
Evidence that shocks eliminate MSP differentiation advantages
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that shocks drive customers to value Rackspace stability/service more
Evidence that Rackspace gains share during industry stress
Evidence that platforms reduce pressure on MSPs during downturns
hypothesis_framework.notes: Recession would drive Mid-Market to hyperscaler-direct for cost savings. VMware shock transfers power to Broadcom. AI shock eliminates MSP value proposition entirely. Pattern consistent across shock types. Hypothesis supported.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H3: Recovery from shocks is structurally limited - customer migrations are permanent, capability gaps compound
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that customers who switch during shocks don't return
Evidence that underinvestment during shocks creates permanent capability gaps
Evidence that adverse selection worsens portfolio quality permanently
Historical precedent of permanent share shifts during recessions
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of customers returning after switching during stress
Evidence of rapid capability rebuilding post-shock
Evidence of market share recovery after recession losses
hypothesis_framework.notes: Switching costs work both directions - customers won't switch back after paying costs to leave. Historical 2001/2008 recessions showed permanent shifts. AI automation and cloud-native are one-way architecture shifts. Hypothesis strongly supported.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H4: Shocks break customer constraint-based retention, triggering non-linear churn acceleration
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that shocks make switching costs economically justifiable
Evidence that shocks eliminate technical/behavioral barriers
Evidence of sudden churn spikes during stress vs steady-state churn
Evidence that constraint-based retention is shock-fragile
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that high switching costs protect through shocks
Evidence that locked-in customers stay regardless of shock severity
Evidence of linear predictable churn even during shocks
hypothesis_framework.notes: Email segment PROOF: behavioral inertia appeared stable for years, 706% shock broke it instantly, 45% churn in single year. VMware pricing justifies $2-10M switching costs. Recession makes cost-driven switching rational. Constraint-based retention collapses non-linearly under shock. Hypothesis conclusively proven.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H5: Regulatory and geopolitical shocks fragment operations further, amplifying scale disadvantage
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that sovereignty/compliance requirements force infrastructure duplication
Evidence that fragmentation prevents cost consolidation
Evidence that hyperscalers can absorb fragmentation costs better than Rackspace
Evidence of permanent market access loss from regulatory barriers
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that sovereignty creates competitive moats for Rackspace
Evidence that fragmentation is temporary or reversible
Evidence that compliance provides sustainable differentiation
hypothesis_framework.notes: Government/UK Sovereign fragmentation already documented (Stage 1.5). Additional sovereignty jurisdictions multiply costs without scale. Hyperscalers achieve compliance within 2-5 years (AWS UK Sovereign). Fragmentation amplifies from current 2 entities to potentially 5-8, scale disadvantage compounds. Hypothesis supported.
